Thanks for the response. The heartbeat setting is set to `scheduler_heartbeat_sec = 5`. I think this is related to a different issue. On the celery worker the number of tasks to be executed is to 32. So though scheduler is kicking of the jobs worker was not firing them. We changed that setting to 64 and now the jobs ran fine!! Please let me know if we need to modify any other settings related to worker!

Thanks

You may want to set up a pool with a number of slots that matches the one on all of your celery workers combined, when it goes over, task instances will show up as status "queued" in the UI.

Then you have to make sure that all tasks reference that default pool. One way to do that at the cluster level is to use the "policy" function in your local settings to enforce that pool even when it's not defined by the author of the pipeline.

We had to make a call on where the first DAG run would be generated when migrating a DAG from 1.5 to 1.6. I didn't want to go all the way to the `min(start_date)` of the DAG for many reasons. So for DAGs with task instance history and no DAG run (thus migrating), we decided to go 5 runs back from the latest recorded task_instance, assuming that the scheduler would re-evaluate the past 5 runs, complete them and keep moving.

The transition created a few problems in a few of our 130+ DAGs at Airbnb, but it was simply a matter of altering the state of a few DAG runs and adapting to the new way of doing things, notably increasing the `concurrency` setting on some large DAGs.

Note that `start_date` is a task level param, and DagRun is a DAG level state. There are some race conditions there. There has always been some race conditions: say if you start a new DAG where task A depends on B and B's start_date is after A's, things would never have run in 1.5.

But yes, there are a few things to iron out here.

@mistercrunch, I rebased and squashed this PR this morning and discovered another sqlite related-regression, which I think confirms the need of this PR since its purpose is precisely to try to catch them before a merge to master. 

The bug is related to a date formated as string in a SQL statement, which is problematic in sqlite (failed build log: https://travis-ci.org/airbnb/airflow/jobs/91355755) and not in mysql (successful build log: https://travis-ci.org/airbnb/airflow/jobs/91355750). 

It is also visible on the current master by simply running: 

```
./run_unit_tests.sh tests.core:WebUiTests.test_dag_views
```

My second commit above is fixing that.

@cwong99 can you post your code? `xcom_pull()` gets the most recent matching XCom, so if you are getting one from the current execution it sounds like you are calling `xcom_push` _before_ `xcom_pull` (because that would push the current value as the most recent one). Try pulling the previous XCom at the beginning of your function and pushing the current one at the end.

For example:

``` python
def fn(ti, **_):
    # first get previous value
    ti.xcom_pull(..., include_prior_dates=True)
    # do stuff
    ...
    # then push latest value
    ti.xcom_push(...)
```

If you are derived from BaseOperator, you can use something like this:

```
        upstream_task_ids = [t.task_id for t in self.upstream_list]
        upstream_data = self.xcom_pull(context=context, task_ids=upstream_task_ids)
```
added some tracing to the code and it appears that the call back is completing and I also checked the database and found the XCOM entries I expected.

@pedrorjbr, I have been thinking of overhauling our s3_hook by using [boto3](https://github.com/boto/boto3). I think this is the library we should use. Because of the very diverse nature of AWS services, I highly recommend we create a hook per underlying service to avoid confusion about where data might be sent or were work might be done. I could create a BaseBoto3Hook that imports the boto3 package and sets up some of the authentication and you could build the container service hook on top. How does that sound?

Nice!
FYI @askeys

Haha, I'm in doubt thinking about it. Facts & thoughts:
- CDH/HDP are not really tested against yet. To make it useful we need a mini hive cluster. Hopefully I have something coming month. CDH and HDP both have different Hive versions and CDH seems to back port fixes a bit more.
- Sqlite is not used / should not be used in production, but comes in handy for development. Sqlite did suffer from regressions and so hampers development if it doesn't work
- Postgres is first class citizen in the os world and even enterprise world is picking it up
- Python 2.7 is mainstream, but python 3 demand is picking up quickly. I expect future major releases of linux distributions to start using python 3 as a standard soon.

So for now it doesn't really matter if we disable CDH/HDP at all. For backend testing it looks nicer to me to test within the same env, but as was mentioned in the other thread having it completely separated has also benefits.

So does this answer your question? I doubt it ;-)

Only certain fields are templated, indicated by the class attributes of each operator. If you add a class attribute to your Operator it should work:

``` python
class SampleOperator(BaseOperator):
    template_fields = ('bash_command',)
    def __init__(...):
        ...
```

Alternatively, use a PythonOperator and pass `provide_context=True`, then use the PythonOperator to print the `ds` object from the context.

Well, with my SampleOperator I can take that macros with this:

``` python
so = SampleOperator(
    task_id='With_exec_datetime',
    message="Executing dag with datetime {{execution_date}}", 
    dag=dag
)
```

And it works fine, but I have a `timedelta(days=1)`, so execution date shows a day before I want. Then I will use other Operators like SimpleHttpOperator to send dates as parameters, and I need the real execution date.

In example, if I program a dag to work every day (`timedelta(days=1)`) and it is scheduled to start day 18/11/2015 at 12:00, it first execution will be 19/11/2015 with `{{execution_date}}` equal to 18/11/2015, but we need `{{execution_date}} + timedelta(days=1)` (that is 19/11/2015).

This is because we need to deal with executions after server failures. This way we can make all requests we need and won't lost data.

Thank you
Closing. #655 was merged.
@mistercrunch May I commend this for your attention. I think you'll like it.

`execution_date` is a `datetime.datetime` object, and timedelta is passed as under the macro namespace (module) and accessible this way `{{ macros.timedelta }}`

This mean you can do things like `{{ (execution_date + macros.timedelta(1)).isoformat()[:10] }}`.

Thank you @mistercrunch, finally my solution is `{{ (execution_date + dag.schedule_interval) }}`. The other side is that now I need to make more operations over these dates. I though that taking more variables with templates is a temporal solution until I understand more Jinja.

Too much thanks

@jbrownlucid,

I can see a few solutions to your problem depending on what you are trying to accomplish : 
- If you need to reuse the HTTP response within a single task, I would recommend building an operator that uses the hook and then does things in Python using this,
- If you need to reuse the response across tasks, I think what you actually want is a different operator using [Xcom](http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/concepts.html#xcoms). The return value is then stored in the database, and retrievable at a later time if execution is somehow stopped. 

The return value from the execute function is not guaranteed to be used in any meaningful way. Also your solution breaks the API of this operator as described in the docs.

Hi, @artwr,

Thanks for the info. I think I'll go with a PythonOperator that uses the responses. The intention here was that returning a value from the HttpOperator’s `execute()` method would have the effect of pushing an XCom, which subsequent operators could use.

PythonOperator will work great though. Thanks again :)

I'm personally not too concerned about collision between external and scheduler triggers runids as individual DAGs will tend to be one or the other and `scheduled__` is safe.

btw part of the reason I took a moment to take the time to review this PR is because it is fairly large and touching the heart of the system. I think most maintainers prefer smaller, targeted PRs. 3 small PRs might make it in faster than one gigantic one.

Digging in a bit further, it seems that it is assumed that dags_folder is a relative path to AIRFLOW_HOME. I think a check on weather dags_folder is an absolute path will solve the issue. Or it should be documented.
Nice, I feel a lot more confident about this PR!
Do you have `depends_on_past` set to True? Is the `concurrency` setting of your DAG is maxed out?
Yes, it wouldn't have to be that way but I think it is the case. I can't remember whether there is a good reason for it or not.

These are my DAG settings:

```
default_args = {
    'owner': 'airflow',
    'depends_on_past': False,
    'start_date': datetime.datetime(2020,01,01),
    'email': ['airflow@airflow.com'],
    'email_on_failure': False,
    'email_on_retry': False,
    'retries': 1,
    'retry_delay': timedelta(minutes=5),
}

dag = DAG("freebayes-regenotype", default_args=default_args,schedule_interval=None)
```

Concurrency is at default 16. Looks like the docs define this setting as:

"concurrency (int) – the number of task instances allowed to run concurrently"

What does that mean precisely? If I have a DAG with 100 tasks in it then 16 at a time will get scheduled? If I have 100 DAGs with 1 task each, then 16 DAG runs will get scheduled? I will play around with this setting, of course, to see the effect. 

Is there no restriction on simultaneous scheduling of multiple runs of the same DAG then? I am certain that I saw a blurb in the documentation somewhere that a task instance for a task would only get scheduled when it's predecessor run has completed.

Sergei,
There is a new [max_active_runs](http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.models.DAG) DAG parameter that restricts the maximum number of dag_runs that can be run. It can be changed when creating a DAG. 

Basically, number of dags currently running <= max_active_runs <= concurrency (maximum number of tasks from the same dag running at the same time across dag_runs).

I hope this helps.

Best,
Arthur
